Hi Maggie, 
Here is some information on ICMA’s Knowledge Network on orientation programs which you may find useful. 
•   This is a link to a newly elected official Orientation handbook for officials in Saint Cloud. This is a comprehensive orientation packet and gives an example of what topics are gone over during an orientation meeting. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302278/Orientation_Handbook_for_Newly_Elected_City_Officials_in_St_Cloud_Minnestoa
•   Here is a similar document, a council orientation manual from the City of Omro. The first 26 pages would be covered in a meeting and the second half would be touched on but things like the municipal code would likely not be gone over in detail. icma.org/Documents/QuestionAnswer/Document/9222
•   In the Employee Recruitment Orientation and Retention handbook from Palo Alto in the New Employee Orientation section from pages 15-24 there is some great information on orientations and what the essential components of an orientation program are.  icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/303069
I hope you find these documents helpful as you plan your new committee member orientation program. In addition to these documents there are others that deal with program orientation on the Knowledge Network and can be found in the documents section (http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents ). 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Alecia Gray
answers.text:
Hi Maggie, 
Brava to you for thinking about orientation for committee members vs. throwing them into the committee work and letting them fend for themselves! I've never led an orientation for municipal committee members; my experience is leading orientation for new employees and sitting on committees myself. However, I feel like the principles are the same, so here my two cents: 
-Give them information that will make them feel successful going into the meetings. Are acronyms throw out with reckless abandon? Then give them a cheat sheet. Is there a hierarchy that they should be familiar with? Then give them an org. chart. Are Roberts Rules of Order the norm? Then tell them the basics. 
-Send them the orientation agenda ahead of time, showing that there will be time at the end for answering questions. When you send the agenda, encourage them to think ahead of time about what questions they might have. When the time comes during orientation for answering those questions, start off by asking "what questions can I answer for you?" vs. "Does anyone have any questions?" It sounds like semantics, but the first way of asking makes it clear that it's okay for them to have questions and that you're ready and willing to answer them. 
-Set clear expectations of what being a committee member will entail. Is each person responsible for chairing or sitting on a sub-committee? Are there positions that need to be filled from people rotating off the committee (e.g. someone to turn in the committee's annual report, someone to update web content, someone to track attendance)? How many meetings are they expected to attend? Do they need to tell anyone if they're not going to make a meeting? 
-Tell them who and what their resources are. If they have questions, do they come to you? If they need a tool to get their work done, do they purchase it and seek reimbursement? Are there by-laws that they need to know? (Here's an example of by-laws for a community choir that has a board and some committees:  http://www.lawrencecivicchoir.org/members/by-laws/ ) 
As far as time goes, I think once you determine your orientation content, you'll have a better sense of the time it will take to discuss that information. That said, if you can keep it to an hour or an hour and a half, I think that's ideal. If you need to go longer than that, make sure that you build in breaks and/or time to get up and stretch and meet other people in the room. 
One more resource for you - I was at a conference exhibit hall a little bit ago and saw that Kansas State University has a board leadership training course they do:  http://www.ksre.ksu.edu/boardleadership/ . I know you said committee, but their board resources might be ripe for extrapolation. 
Again, kudos to you for thinking about providing orientation. The fact that you're even thinking about that means that you're aware that committee members don't simply arrive knowing how to be effective. 
Alecia Gray 
KU Public Management Center 
agray@ku.edu

author: Maggie Darr
text:
Does your municipality hold an orientation for newly appointed committee members?  If so,

What topics are on the agenda?
How long is the orientation?
What kinds of supplemental documents are shared with committee members?

Thank you in advance for any input!
title: Committee Orientation
